awd_titl_txt: Dissertation Research:  Public Service Provision and Pockets of Effectiveness
awd_abstract_narration:
SES-1636972
Ivan Ermakoff
Michael Roll
University of Wisconsin Madison

The effective provision of basic public services is essential for reducing poverty in the developing world. In many countries, however, government agencies in charge of providing services like water, security, health services, and education are dysfunctional. Often, public sector reforms undertaken with international support have failed to remedy this situation. That is why the capacity of some government agencies to meet public service requirements in contexts marked by governmental ineffectiveness requires systematic attention. Focusing on subnational variation in organizational performance, this project examines why and how these organizations achieve satisfactory levels of performance. By exploring the micro-processes and mechanisms through which these pockets of effective public service provision emerge and become institutionalized, this project makes a theoretical contribution to understanding the origins of subnational institutional variation, institutional change, and development. The findings will also be of relevance to policymakers and international agencies working on corruption and public services. 

Using a matched pairs design, the project compares government agencies in Nigeria that differ substantially in terms of public service provision. Based on semi-structured interviews, focus group discussions, non-participant observation, surveys, and the analysis of administrative data, process tracing and within-case analysis will be employed for identifying the processes and mechanisms at work and cross-case analysis for added leverage.

por.por_cntn:
The effective provision of basic public services is essential for reducing poverty in the developing world. In many countries, however, government agencies in charge of providing services like water, security, health, and education are dysfunctional. Often, public sector reforms undertaken with international support have failed to remedy this situation. That is why the capacity of some government agencies to meet public service requirements in contexts marked by governmental ineffectiveness requires systematic attention.

This research project focused on the subnational variation in organizational performance in an overall context of weak government agency performance (Nigeria). It looked at agencies that perform much better than other, similar agencies in the same challenging institutional context. By focusing on those agencies that do a good job of actually providing the public goods and services they are supposed to provide and comparing it with those that don't, it aimed at understanding better how these positive outliers emerge.

Data collected include 135 semi-structured interviews, non-participant observation, a novel survey, and internal administrative data. Using process tracing and cross-case as well as within-case comparisons for identifying the processes and mechanisms that explain the variation in organizational performance, the results were as follows. 

First, government agencies with female directors were found to be more effective in terms of public service provision than those led by men, on average, in the same challenging environment. This can be explained by the way female directors are recruited. Women are not usually members of the informal elite networks or all-male ?old boys? networks through which senior officials are often pre-selected in patrimonial settings. If women are recruited to these top bureaucratic positions at all, they tend to be recruited based on a different set of criteria: expertise (technical qualification and experience) and previously demonstrated incorruptibility. With political backing, these female directors then manage internal organizational changes that improve agency performance and service provision. While this finding is particularly about gender, its broader message is that the social and power structure of a society in combination with the recruitment criteria for top officials shape the conditions for successful organizational change and service provision.

Second, internal organizational change processes in settings of systemic corruption differ from how they are often assumed to work. Instead of firing a large proportion of staff, especially those involved in corruption, these staff are often internally disciplined but kept within the organization. More importantly, however, those members of staff who have previously tried to work to improve service delivery are now provided with reliable and more systematic support. This shows that corruption is less a behavioral feature of individuals or groups but an organizational phenomenon which can be influenced through appropriate internal organizational reforms with political support.

Third, the project found that bureaucratic agency and ?political management? (the way top bureaucrats ?manage? their political environment by generating political protection and support) are crucial for organizational change and for creating pockets of effectiveness. Top bureaucrats mediate between political demands on the one hand and internal organizational needs on the other to make organizational change possible. While they do have certain goals in mind (e.g. more effective public service delivery) they are very pragmatic in working toward it in the challenging day-to-day setting they find themselves in.

These findings contribute to how subnational variation in government agency performance in developing countries is understood and how organizational change can be explained. Beyond this academic impact, the results may also influence how policymakers and international development agencies try to support government agency reform in developing countries. Approaches that identify and understand existing pockets of effectiveness may be a first step. A second step can be to develop approaches that support other government agencies to improve public service delivery more effectively and thereby help to reduce poverty and inequality in the developing world.
